aws::graph::propositions: # Boeing B75N1 Aircraft Accident in Mesa, Arizona
The accident occurred in Mesa, Arizona.
The accident occurred on March 19, 2013, at 12:48 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Boeing B75N1.
The defining event was loss of control on ground.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was WPR13CA162.
The aircraft registration was N47964.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were 2 occupants with no injuries.
The aircraft was tailwheel-equipped.
The pilot reported the airplane tracked left of the runway centerline during deceleration after touchdown.
The pilot applied corrective control inputs.
The airplane continued to track left despite corrective control inputs.
The airplane departed the runway.
The right wing contacted the ground.
The right wing was substantially damaged during the runway excursion.
The aircraft had recently completed a 100-hour annual inspection.
The tailwheel suspension strut was modified with a different type of strut during the inspection.
The pilot reported the new strut did not compress on landing until after right rudder was applied.
Review of the tailwheel strut design revealed the strut only affects vertical movement of the tailwheel.
The tailwheel strut has no lateral control effects.
Postaccident examination of the airplane revealed no evidence of mechanical failure.
Postaccident examination revealed no evidence of malfunction that would have precluded normal operation.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of the accident to be the pilot's failure to maintain directional control during the landing roll.
The findings included aircraft directional control was not attained/maintained.
The findings included personnel issues related to aircraft control by the pilot.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Mesa, Arizona

## Date & Time: 
March 19, 2013, 12:48 Local

## Aircraft:
Boeing B75N1

## Defining Event:
Loss of control on ground

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
WPR13CA162

## Registration:
N47964

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 None

## Analysis

The pilot reported that as the tailwheel-equipped airplane decelerated after touchdown, it tracked left of the runway centerline. He applied corrective control inputs; however, the airplane continued to track left and departed the runway. The right wing contacted the ground and was substantially damaged during the runway excursion. The pilot reported that during the recently completed 100-hour annual inspection, the tailwheel suspension strut was modified with a different type of strut and that the new strut did not compress on landing until after right rudder was applied. However, review of the tailwheel strut design revealed that the strut only affects the vertical movement of the tailwheel, and has no lateral control effects. Postaccident examination of the airplane revealed no evidence of a mechanical failure or malfunction that would have precluded normal operation.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:
The pilot's failure to maintain directional control during the landing roll.

## Findings

| | |
|-|-|
| Aircraft | Directional control - Not attained/maintained |
| Personnel issues | Aircraft control - Pilot |

---
